message.text:
haproxy-m1-dm     | [NOTICE]   (1) : haproxy version is 3.0.12-21a355d
haproxy-m1-dm     | [ALERT]    (1) : config : [/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:30] : 'server http_back/web1' : could not resolve address 'contapa2-m1-dm-1'.
haproxy-m1-dm     | [ALERT]    (1) : config : [/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:31] : 'server http_back/web2' : could not resolve address 'contapa2-m1-dm-2'.
haproxy-m1-dm     | [ALERT]    (1) : config : [/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:32] : 'server http_back/web3' : could not resolve address 'contapa2-m1-dm-3'.

parts.text:
haproxy-m1-dm     | [NOTICE]   (1) : haproxy version is 3.0.12-21a355d
haproxy-m1-dm     | [ALERT]    (1) : config : [/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:30] : 'server http_back/web1' : could not resolve address 'contapa2-m1-dm-1'.
haproxy-m1-dm     | [ALERT]    (1) : config : [/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:31] : 'server http_back/web2' : could not resolve address 'contapa2-m1-dm-2'.
haproxy-m1-dm     | [ALERT]    (1) : config : [/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:32] : 'server http_back/web3' : could not resolve address 'contapa2-m1-dm-3'.

response.value: I can see that HAProxy is trying to resolve servers with names `contapa2-m1-dm-1`, `contapa2-m1-dm-2`, and `contapa2-m1-dm-3`, but these don't match the actual container names in your Docker Compose setup. Let me check your HAProxy configuration and Docker Compose file to fix this.

I can see the issue. When you use Docker Compose's `deploy.replicas` feature, the container names are generated as `<service_name>-<replica_number>`, not `<service_name>-<project_name>-<replica_number>`. The service name is `contapa2-m1-dm`, so the containers should be named:
- `contapa2-m1-dm-1`
- `contapa2-m1-dm-2`
- `contapa2-m1-dm-3`

However, the actual container naming in Docker Compose depends on the project name. Let me check what containers are actually running to confirm the exact names:

autoApproveInfo.value: _Auto approval denied by rule [`/\{.+\}/`](settings_7 "View rule in settings")_

response.value:
The issue is that Docker Compose creates container names with the project name included. Since your folder is "Milestone 1", Docker likely creates containers like `milestone1-contapa2-m1-dm-1`, `milestone1-contapa2-m1-dm-2`, etc.

However, for service discovery within Docker Compose networks, you should use the **service name** directly, and Docker's DNS will handle load balancing across all replicas automatically. You don't need to specify individual container names.

Let me fix the HAProxy configuration:

edits.text:
backend http_back
    balance roundrobin
    option httpchk GET /
    server-template web 3 contapa2-m1-dm:80 check

response.value:
I've updated the HAProxy configuration to use `server-template`, which works better with Docker Compose scaled services. The `server-template web 3 contapa2-m1-dm:80 check` line will create 3 server entries that all point to the service name `contapa2-m1-dm`, and Docker's internal DNS will distribute the requests across all 3 replicas.

Now restart your Docker Compose services to apply the changes:

commandLine.original: cd "c:\Users\David\OneDrive - Thomas More\Semester 3\Linux Web Services\git\Milestone 1"; docker-compose restart haproxy

response.value:
I've fixed the HAProxy configuration. The issue was that it was trying to resolve individual container names (`contapa2-m1-dm-1`, etc.) which don't exist in Docker's DNS. 

The solution is to use `server-template` which creates multiple server entries pointing to the service name `contapa2-m1-dm`. Docker Compose's internal DNS will automatically distribute requests across all 3 replicas.

To apply the changes, restart the HAProxy container:
```powershell
docker-compose restart haproxy
```

This should resolve the DNS errors and HAProxy will be able to load balance across your 3 web server replicas.

The solution is to use `server-template` which creates multiple server entries pointing to the service name `contapa2-m1-dm`. Docker Compose's internal DNS will automatically distribute requests across all 3 replicas.

To apply the changes, restart the HAProxy container:
